body:
> "Strive to enter by the narrow gate; for many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not be able." Luke 13:24

The common opinion of theologians is that few will be saved compared to the many who are damned. This is not to say that this opinion is absolutely true, but it is the more common, nor that there are not many who are saved, only that they are "few" in comparison with the many who are damned. 

> You will hear Saint Gregory saying clearly, "Many attain to faith, but few to the heavenly kingdom." Saint Anselm declares, "There are few who are saved." Saint Augustine states even more clearly, "Therefore, few are saved in comparison to those who are damned." The most terrifying, however, is Saint Jerome. At the end of his life, in the presence of his disciples, he spoke these dreadful words: "Out of one hundred thousand people whose lives have always been bad, you will find barely one who is worthy of indulgence."

This kind of sermon is intended to act as a "wake up call" to those who are being reassured that, while they live bad lives, their lives are actually "not so bad":

> Pious souls, you may leave; this sermon is not for you. Its sole purpose is to contain the pride of libertines who cast the holy fear of God out of their heart and join forces with the devil who, according to the sentiment of Eusebius, damns souls by reassuring them.

It is not intended to discourage people towards sins of despair, but rather encourage people to be the very best they can be, to "strive" to do so. As the sermon states:

> One of our brothers, Blessed Giles, was in the habit of saying that if only one man were going to be damned, he would do all he could to make sure he was not that man.

I imagine no one would like to be that man, but rather instead would like to act to not be such a person. A house is secured against dangers of thieves breaking in, or animals and pests, or natural disasters. So too our souls are subject to dangers of temptation and one would think that a man thinking like "Blessed Giles" would seek to secure the soul against such dangers by prayer, fasting, almsgiving, etc.

> Know you not that they that run in the race, all run indeed, but one receiveth the prize? So run that you may obtain. 1 Corinthians 9:24

Hopefully sermons like this inspire good people to be the very best they can be, and bad people to become good, that they may train just as athletes in a contest so that they may obtain the "prize" of eternal life.

Sermon text link: https://www.olrl.org/snt_docs/fewness.shtml

guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

A house is secured against dangers of thieves breaking in, or animals and pests, or natural disasters. So too our souls are subject to dangers of temptation and one would think that a man thinking like "Blessed Giles" would seek to secure the soul against such dangers by prayer, fasting, almsgiving, etc.

> Know you not that they that run in the race, all run indeed, but one receiveth the prize? So run that you may obtain. 1 Corinthians 9:24

Hopefully sermons like this inspire good people to be the very best they can be, and bad people to become good, that they may train just as athletes in a contest so that they may obtain the "prize" of eternal life.

body:
To be honest, the narrow door puzzles me... unless it is used as inspiration or a wake-up call to how you are actually living as you suggest.  A reminder that we fall short without Jesus.  An attempt to keep the KoG on earth without a semblance of corruption.  It is a terrible sight to see a Christian committing sin, it just cannot happen...

...with that said though, few are saved to me implies than Satan is largely victorious, which seems contrary to the will of God.

An undeniable truth about God is that he WANTS all to be saved... and for not all to be saved, what does that say about His will be done?  Does our will supersede His even in the time of judgement?  

Or is His will the destruction of sin and death? And upon that destruction, we are saved...

Or is His will the destruction of souls?  Destroying His creation.

To me, A Good Christian follows Christ out of love for His actions and teachings as it pertains to loving your enemy, forgiveness of ones neighbor, resistance to violence, resistance to imposed poverty, etc... A Bad Christian comes to Jesus out of fear for their own salvation, because even still, that Christian only thinks of themselves.  A worse Christian still is one who does neither.  With that said, I can't help but think all will be restored and all will find their place in the Kingdom.

body:
> A worse Christian still is one who does neither.

Wouldn't that just be an unbeliever? And in that case I think they are actually better than the false Christians, because they at least don't use God's name as an excuse for evil. It's kind of convenient how they twisted the third commandment into a weird purity rule about not literally saying God's name to avoid this implication. And now it's even worse, because most translations change it to say this instead of its original meaning.
